summary: This case involved an application for conditional leave to appeal to the Privy Council from a judgment of the West Africa Court of Appeal (WACA) dated 7th March, 1940. The Co-Plaintiff-Appellant argued that the judgment was final and thus entitled them to appeal as of right under Rule 3(a) of the West African (Appeal to Privy Council) Order-in-Council, 1930. The WACA held that the judgment was interlocutory, not final, because it did not finally dispose of the matter in dispute and left the suit pending in the lower court. Applying the test from Salman v. Warner, the court emphasized that a final judgment must conclusively determine the litigation. The court also referenced McDonald v. Belcher, noting that the trial judge had not made a final finding on the issue of rents and profits from Himan lands. The application for leave to appeal was dismissed with costs.
legalKeywords: West African Court of Appeal Ordinance
verdict: Application for conditional leave to appeal dismissed with costs.
citations: Salman v. Warner and Others, 1891, 1 Q.B.D. 734
Standard Discount Co. v. La Grange (4)
McDonald and Belcher and Others, 1904 A.C. 429
rationaleHighlights: A final judgment must finally determine the matter in dispute; if the decision allows the action to continue, it is interlocutory.
The court applied the test from Salman v. Warner to determine finality.
No final determination was made on rents and profits, leaving the suit pending.
Applicant failed to seek clarification of ambiguous judgment, as advised by Privy Council precedent.
confidenceNotes: High confidence in factual accuracy based on clear judicial reasoning and cited authorities.
